ResourceHeader.Description:
ST5 mission was a part of the NASA New Millennium Program to flight-validate new concepts and technologies. ST5 project designed, built and operated three 25 kg spacecraft utilizing breakthrough technologies. It demonstrated the ability to achieve accurate, research-quality scientific measurements while operating the 3 micro-satellites as a single constellation.
ST5 launched on March 22, 2006 onboard the Pegasus rocket out of Vandenberg. Approximately 10 min after launch, ejected 3 min apart frisbee-style. Mission duration was 90 days, 7 day launch and early orbit period, mission completed June 20, 2006. The orbit was 105.6 deg inclination (full sun orbit), ~300 km perigee, ~4500 km apogee, 136 minute period.
The ST5 micro-satellites were developed by NASA/GSFC in partnership with industry, other NASA centers and academia. They were built within tight volume and mass constraints, low-power and low voltage, size ~50 cm x 48 cm, integral card cage structure (for C&DH, PSE), mass ~25 kg. Spacecraft-induced magnetic field effects as measured at the magnetometer sensor location less than 10 nT (d.c.), 5 nT (a.c.). The spacecraft carried a science demonstration instrument, a high-resolution, high-precission, three-axis flux-gate magnetometer.
The ST5 constellation returned unprecedented data on the Earth's auroral currents as well as on the crustal magnetic field. ST5 provided for the first time simultaneous multi-point measurements of auroral electric currents at low altitudes, which allow us to separate temporal and spatial variations of these currents. ST5 provided a unique data set on the Earth's crustal magnetic field, which is a consequence of both the constellation flying, and the enhanced resolution from the low perigee, lower than any previous geomagnetism mission.
